subject: Self Care
title: Meaning vs. Pleasure
description: A short lesson to help you apply Meaning vs. Pleasure.

hook.text: The party was fun but empty. The volunteer shift was hard but fulfilling. Pleasure and meaning are different paths to happiness.

buildup.text: Hedonic happiness comes from pleasure. Eudaimonic happiness comes from meaning. Both matter, but meaning lasts longer.

discovery.text: Studies show that meaning-based happiness predicts long-term well-being better than pleasure-based happiness across cultures.

twist.text: Meaningful activities feel harder in the moment. Parenting, volunteering, and creating are effortful but deeply satisfying.

climax.text: Audit your week: how much time goes to pleasure vs. meaning? If meaning is starved, add one purpose-driven activity.

punchline.text: Pleasure fades fast. Meaning compounds over time. Invest in both.

quiz.question: Which type of happiness better predicts long-term well-being?
